title: Is it racist for a white person to not like afro hair? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not racist to have a preference. I’m black so I know a bit about my community. The funny thing is, a lot of black people don’t like Afro hair. There’s been a shift in recent days but I know many black women who much prefer Brazilian or Indian hair on their heads and many black men who agree. That’s not racist in and of itself. However, keeping in mind the historical, social, and psychological effects of racism I would like every person who sees kinky Afro hair and recoils, to question themselves. Whether you’re black or white, you should try and question it. Why don’t you like it? Is it a real, natural preference? Is it because it’s something you don’t see often? Could it be the fact that for a long time, Afro hair was socially unacceptable. Because it grows on the heads of black people, it was ugly. Because up until recently and still today, black hair is seen as unkempt and inappropriate in a professional environment. Do you know if any of this influences you? Whenever people ask if something is racist I implore them to look deep down and think about these things. I don’t believe that it is racist to have a preference. I prefer Afro hair because it is what I am accustomed to. Perhaps a white person would feel the same about their own hair. None of these are racist. What might be racist is disliking the things that racists, for centuries, have been telling us to dislike. And on a final note, having a few racist tendencies does not a racist make. I think everyone has a few biases and beliefs that are not kosher. So long as you don’t act upon them, it’s generally fine. I wouldn’t suggest going around and saying you don’t like Afro hair though. I wouldn’t go around saying I don’t like straight hair because it’s probably a little insulting. Be respectful.

My youngest son’s friends, with types 3 and 4 hair, smell so much better after playing outside than my son. He has that medium-blonde, straight, stringy, white kid hair that smells (and sometimes looks) like a wet dog after exercise in the heat. Nothing I can do about it - just a genetic thing - but I don’t think I’m racist against small sweaty white boys just because I think they smell like wet dogs. Similarly, if someone didn’t like very curly hair, that’s their thing. Just don’t be insulting people about it.
